messages: f9d57889f77f4fb9944bd70522c40d1e (02:00): Okay, so I want to display a table showing products that are sold and display how many of each product were sold, the price they were sold at, and if a product was sold at more than one price it displays at each differnt price (how many were sold a that price and how many were sold reguardless of price). So there are 4 columns: Product Name, # sold at price, price, # sold at any price. All this information is in a single table. I want th

f9d57889f77f4fb9944bd70522c40d1e (02:02): Earlier I was trying to get something I had set up to do this to work, but couldn't seem to get it the way I had been doing it with Union and such. So I'm thinking explaining what I am trying to do would be better and maybe someone has a suggestion how to go about doing it.

b6e49b1f06deb5e70480cdcb292ac93b (02:16): delete FROM `completed_survey_headers` left join companies on completed_survey_headers.company_id=companies.id where companies.id is null;

b6e49b1f06deb5e70480cdcb292ac93b (02:24): ah, i figured it out, i have to say 'delete completed_survey_headers from' since theres more than one table involved in the delete

f09641afb500f06338770e1f5f2fc3ca (02:41): is there any way to left join two tables by a first priority, and then if it fails by a second priority in one query
f09641afb500f06338770e1f5f2fc3ca (02:41): aka left join table on t1.itema=t2.itema (if it fails, then try) t1.itemb = t2.itemb
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (02:43): You might be able to use an IF statement.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (02:44): !man if statement
ac5c74b64b4b8352ef2f181affb5ac2a (02:44): (IF Statement) : http://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql/en/IF_Statement.html
1f720e3dda007387bece3dffeab0c482 (02:47): Doesn't the IF statement have to be in a stored procedure or function ?
03feb5473d8ff0000b5b01e8feba9ca3 (02:58): howdy
6ecc2cbd8ba582fe8847cd33a20772d5 (03:00): hi all
6ecc2cbd8ba582fe8847cd33a20772d5 (03:01): i created a database with innoDB tables. When I now run SHOW VARIABLES LIKE 'table_type' it reports "MyIsam" ?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:01): scotdb: Indeed.
b323fa7d8028b31a502e11e92243a109 (03:03): inzanez, switch to that database and run this:

03feb5473d8ff0000b5b01e8feba9ca3 (03:03): anyone know if it is possible to get echo "select * from tbname" | mysql dbname to also display the tabulated output you get from within mysql interactive output.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:03): inzanez: Er...that's variables. Did you try SHOW TABLE STATUS?
b323fa7d8028b31a502e11e92243a109 (03:03): SHOW TABLE STATUS LIKE 'table'
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:04): Or SHOW TABLE STATUS FROM database LIKE 'table'
6ecc2cbd8ba582fe8847cd33a20772d5 (03:04): hm...it shows innodb, ok :) Hm, strange. thanks! :)
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:04): dos000: You can use mysql -e to execute queries.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:04): inzanez: SHOW VARIABLES is the overall server, like if InnoDB is enabled, the query cache, etc.
f87153ef41cc6ccb4f8e8dcf0357de7b (03:05): what's the difference between "Linux (x86, glibc-2.2, "standard" is static, gcc)" and "Linux (x86)"?
f87153ef41cc6ccb4f8e8dcf0357de7b (03:05): is the later dynamically linked to glibc-2.3?
6ecc2cbd8ba582fe8847cd33a20772d5 (03:06): Xorlev: thanks :)
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:07): hi folks - anyway to backup and recreate a mysql db using phpmyadmin?  i tried the Export - but that doesn't actually create the db, only the tables.

f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:07): Carrera: This is just an educated guess, but I believe the statically linked one has glibc already loaded into it, while the dynamically linked one uses an existing glibc on the server.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:08): salamandyr: To create the database it just uses one line: CREATE DATABASE dbname;. It's the tables that actually structure it.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:08): ah, okay Xorlev - thanks
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:08): but no way to do a complete dump / restore?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:08): It does do a complete dump.
ae201d3146cf3739ba1728ef0c6e662d (03:08): salamandyr: I strongly recommend using the mysqldump tool, it is much faster
f87153ef41cc6ccb4f8e8dcf0357de7b (03:08): thanks Xorlev
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:09): I agree with Fullmoon, but if that isn't possible...phpMyAdmin does export everything.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:09): The database is almost like a grouping.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:09): A named group of tables.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:09): well, i am migratin from one server to another - the migration "missed" a few of the databases

ae201d3146cf3739ba1728ef0c6e662d (03:09): salamandyr: You can simply load the data from the dump by executing it, if you look at the exported file you will see that it is just a bunch of database-statements
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:10): As I said, the database its self has no structure. It's the CREATE TABLE statements that make the magic happen.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:10): but what about user privs, etc?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:11): They're stored in the mysql table.
ae201d3146cf3739ba1728ef0c6e662d (03:11): salamandyr: Those are actually not more than entries in the ‚Äúuser‚Äù table in the ‚Äúmysql‚Äù database
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:12): so i have to manually recreate that, it seems
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:12): If you're migrating servers...just shut off the server and copy over the datadir. That's the easiest way.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:12): Err, shut off MySQL
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:12): Then when the new server boots up it reads the datadir and all the databases are there, same for user permissions.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:13): slightly diff versions of mysql - 4.0.27 to 4.1.19
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:13): should that cause any probs?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:13): You really should move to 5 if at all possible...4.1 is an older version now
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:14): actually that isn't possible
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:14): dont suppose the datadir is in an obvious location?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:14): You shouldn't have any trouble between 4.0 and 4.1
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:14): /var/lib/mysql on my box
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:15): But you can run SHOW VARIABLES LIKE 'datadir' to find out.
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:15): http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/upgrade.html
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:15): Everything you need right there.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:15): i'll try a copy, thanks
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:15): http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/4.1/en/upgrading-from-4-0.html
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:15): Xorlev - unfortunately i cannot upgrade - i'm using cpanel for my customers - it's still on a 4.x
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:16): and to keep cpanel managing it i have to run with their supported versions
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:16): salamandyr: 5.0 is available in WHM, and you can always do it manually and add a file somewhre I can't remember which disabled MySQL updates.
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:16): i'm not sure that 5.0 would give me any real benefit?
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (03:17): Stored procedures are sexy.
df8168dd9d028c727ce1d7da65e140b1 (03:17): yes, and so are triggers
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:17): ya, but i'm not using those features with mysql
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:17): it's just to support things like postnuke, typo3, etc
7f464ba8299fafa9f705637037e8289f (03:20): and i must confess to doing all of my custom development in postgres :)
